article: A boy of 14 has become the youngest student to win a place at Cambridge University. Arran Fernandez, who was _ at home by his father, Neil, will _ a mathematics degree at Fitzwilliam College next month and he hopes to have a career as a research mathematician to work out the Riemann hypothesis that has confused the brightest minds. It will make him the youngest Cambridge student _ 14-year-old William Pitt the Younger studied there in 1773. Last night the child genius said: "I am looking forward to going to the _ . I have started the first-year books _ and it is all right, not too _ . I can understand it. I am excited about going to Cambridge, _ I am used to making records about being the youngest in education. It isn't the youngest moment that is so important to me-- _ I'm more interested in going to Cambridge than comparing _ with other people who go there." But because of his age he will not be able to join in many of the alcohol-fuelled festivities traditionally _ to Freshers' Week. "I don't think I'm missing too much fun," he insisted. "Even if I was 18, I wouldn't want to go out _ . " Arran, _ plans to join the bird-watching society instead and go boating while at university, was five when he _ the youngest person to be _ a GCSE (General Certificated of Secondary Education), after passing maths. He was offered the _ to learn at Cambridge in 2010, when he was 14, on the condition he gained an A-level in physics, which he _ with an A+ grade. Arran had already gained an A grade in further maths last year. Cambridge also asked him to attend three GCSEs in subjects which were not related to maths and physics to _ his knowledge. He gained A+s in English literature and French and an A in English language this summer.
